95ğ“€´How these papers have been placed in sequence will be made manifest in
96ğ“€´the reading of them. All needless matters have been eliminated, so that
97ğ“€´a history almost at variance with the possibilities of later-day belief
98ğ“€´may stand forth as simple fact. There is throughout no statement of
99ğ“€´past things wherein memory may err, for all the records chosen are
100ğ“€´exactly contemporary, given from the standpoints and within the range
101ğ“€´of knowledge of those who made them.

113ğ“€´JONATHAN HARKERâ€™S JOURNAL

118ğ“€´_3 May. Bistritz._--Left Munich at 8:35 P. M., on 1st May, arriving at
119ğ“€´Vienna early next morning; should have arrived at 6:46, but train was an
120ğ“€´hour late. Buda-Pesth seems a wonderful place, from the glimpse which I
121ğ“€´got of it from the train and the little I could walk through the
122ğ“€´streets. I feared to go very far from the station, as we had arrived
123ğ“€´late and would start as near the correct time as possible. The
124ğ“€´impression I had was that we were leaving the West and entering the
125ğ“€´East; the most western of splendid bridges over the Danube, which is
126ğ“€´here of noble width and depth, took us among the traditions of Turkish
127ğ“€´rule.
128ğ“€´
129ğ“€´We left in pretty good time, and came after nightfall to Klausenburgh.
130ğ“€´Here I stopped for the night at the Hotel Royale. I had for dinner, or
131ğ“€´rather supper, a chicken done up some way with red pepper, which was
132ğ“€´very good but thirsty. (_Mem._, get recipe for Mina.) I asked the
133ğ“€´waiter, and he said it was called â€œpaprika hendl,â€ and that, as it was a
134ğ“€´national dish, I should be able to get it anywhere along the
135ğ“€´Carpathians. I found my smattering of German very useful here; indeed, I
136ğ“€´donâ€™t know how I should be able to get on without it.
137ğ“€´
138ğ“€´Having had some time at my disposal when in London, I had visited the
139ğ“€´British Museum, and made search among the books and maps in the library
140ğ“€´regarding Transylvania; it had struck me that some foreknowledge of the
141ğ“€´country could hardly fail to have some importance in dealing with a
142ğ“€´nobleman of that country. I find that the district he named is in the
143ğ“€´extreme east of the country, just on the borders of three states,
144ğ“€´Transylvania, Moldavia and Bukovina, in the midst of the Carpathian
145ğ“€´mountains; one of the wildest and least known portions of Europe. I was
146ğ“€´not able to light on any map or work giving the exact locality of the
147ğ“€´Castle Dracula, as there are no maps of this country as yet to compare
148ğ“€´with our own Ordnance Survey maps; but I found that Bistritz, the post
149ğ“€´town named by Count Dracula, is a fairly well-known place. I shall enter
150ğ“€´here some of my notes, as they may refresh my memory when I talk over my
151ğ“€´travels with Mina.
152ğ“€´
153ğ“€´In the population of Transylvania there are four distinct nationalities:
154ğ“€´Saxons in the South, and mixed with them the Wallachs, who are the
155ğ“€´descendants of the Dacians; Magyars in the West, and Szekelys in the
156ğ“€´East and North. I am going among the latter, who claim to be descended
157ğ“€´from Attila and the Huns. This may be so, for when the Magyars conquered
158ğ“€´the country in the eleventh century they found the Huns settled in it. I
159ğ“€´read that every known superstition in the world is gathered into the
160ğ“€´horseshoe of the Carpathians, as if it were the centre of some sort of
161ğ“€´imaginative whirlpool; if so my stay may be very interesting. (_Mem._, I
162ğ“€´must ask the Count all about them.)
163ğ“€´
164ğ“€´I did not sleep well, though my bed was comfortable enough, for I had
165ğ“€´all sorts of queer dreams. There was a dog howling all night under my
166ğ“€´window, which may have had something to do with it; or it may have been
167ğ“€´the paprika, for I had to drink up all the water in my carafe, and was
168ğ“€´still thirsty. Towards morning I slept and was wakened by the continuous
169ğ“€´knocking at my door, so I guess I must have been sleeping soundly then.
170ğ“€´I had for breakfast more paprika, and a sort of porridge of maize flour
171ğ“€´which they said was â€œmamaliga,â€ and egg-plant stuffed with forcemeat, a
172ğ“€´very excellent dish, which they call â€œimpletata.â€ (_Mem._, get recipe
173ğ“€´for this also.) I had to hurry breakfast, for the train started a little
174ğ“€´before eight, or rather it ought to have done so, for after rushing to
175ğ“€´the station at 7:30 I had to sit in the carriage for more than an hour
176ğ“€´before we began to move. It seems to me that the further east you go the
177ğ“€´more unpunctual are the trains. What ought they to be in China?
178ğ“€´
179ğ“€´All day long we seemed to dawdle through a country which was full of
180ğ“€´beauty of every kind. Sometimes we saw little towns or castles on the
181ğ“€´top of steep hills such as we see in old missals; sometimes we ran by
182ğ“€´rivers and streams which seemed from the wide stony margin on each side
183ğ“€´of them to be subject to great floods. It takes a lot of water, and
184ğ“€´running strong, to sweep the outside edge of a river clear. At every
185ğ“€´station there were groups of people, sometimes crowds, and in all sorts
186ğ“€´of attire. Some of them were just like the peasants at home or those I
187ğ“€´saw coming through France and Germany, with short jackets and round hats
188ğ“€´and home-made trousers; but others were very picturesque. The women
189ğ“€´looked pretty, except when you got near them, but they were very clumsy
190ğ“€´about the waist. They had all full white sleeves of some kind or other,
191ğ“€´and most of them had big belts with a lot of strips of something
192ğ“€´fluttering from them like the dresses in a ballet, but of course there
193ğ“€´were petticoats under them. The strangest figures we saw were the
194ğ“€´Slovaks, who were more barbarian than the rest, with their big cow-boy
195ğ“€´hats, great baggy dirty-white trousers, white linen shirts, and enormous
196ğ“€´heavy leather belts, nearly a foot wide, all studded over with brass
197ğ“€´nails. They wore high boots, with their trousers tucked into them, and
198ğ“€´had long black hair and heavy black moustaches. They are very
199ğ“€´picturesque, but do not look prepossessing. On the stage they would be
200ğ“€´set down at once as some old Oriental band of brigands. They are,
201ğ“€´however, I am told, very harmless and rather wanting in natural
202ğ“€´self-assertion.
203ğ“€´
204ğ“€´It was on the dark side of twilight when we got to Bistritz, which is a
205ğ“€´very interesting old place. Being practically on the frontier--for the
206ğ“€´Borgo Pass leads from it into Bukovina--it has had a very stormy
207ğ“€´existence, and it certainly shows marks of it. Fifty years ago a series
208ğ“€´of great fires took place, which made terrible havoc on five separate
209ğ“€´occasions. At the very beginning of the seventeenth century it underwent
210ğ“€´a siege of three weeks and lost 13,000 people, the casualties of war
211ğ“€´proper being assisted by famine and disease.
212ğ“€´
213ğ“€´Count Dracula had directed me to go to the Golden Krone Hotel, which I
214ğ“€´found, to my great delight, to be thoroughly old-fashioned, for of
215ğ“€´course I wanted to see all I could of the ways of the country. I was
216ğ“€´evidently expected, for when I got near the door I faced a
217ğ“€´cheery-looking elderly woman in the usual peasant dress--white
218ğ“€´undergarment with long double apron, front, and back, of coloured stuff
219ğ“€´fitting almost too tight for modesty. When I came close she bowed and
220ğ“€´said, â€œThe Herr Englishman?â€ â€œYes,â€ I said, â€œJonathan Harker.â€ She
221ğ“€´smiled, and gave some message to an elderly man in white shirt-sleeves,
222ğ“€´who had followed her to the door. He went, but immediately returned with
223ğ“€´a letter:--
224ğ“€´
225ğ“€´     â€œMy Friend.--Welcome to the Carpathians. I am anxiously expecting
226ğ“€´     you. Sleep well to-night. At three to-morrow the diligence will
227ğ“€´     start for Bukovina; a place on it is kept for you. At the Borgo
228ğ“€´     Pass my carriage will await you and will bring you to me. I trust
229ğ“€´     that your journey from London has been a happy one, and that you
230ğ“€´     will enjoy your stay in my beautiful land.
231ğ“€´
232ğ“€´â€œYour friend,
233ğ“€´
234ğ“€´â€œDRACULA.â€
235ğ“€´
236ğ“€´
237ğ“€´_4 May._--I found that my landlord had got a letter from the Count,
238ğ“€´directing him to secure the best place on the coach for me; but on
239ğ“€´making inquiries as to details he seemed somewhat reticent, and
240ğ“€´pretended that he could not understand my German. This could not be
241ğ“€´true, because up to then he had understood it perfectly; at least, he
242ğ“€´answered my questions exactly as if he did. He and his wife, the old
243ğ“€´lady who had received me, looked at each other in a frightened sort of
244ğ“€´way. He mumbled out that the money had been sent in a letter, and that
245ğ“€´was all he knew. When I asked him if he knew Count Dracula, and could
246ğ“€´tell me anything of his castle, both he and his wife crossed themselves,
247ğ“€´and, saying that they knew nothing at all, simply refused to speak
248ğ“€´further. It was so near the time of starting that I had no time to ask
249ğ“€´any one else, for it was all very mysterious and not by any means
250ğ“€´comforting.
251ğ“€´
252ğ“€´Just before I was leaving, the old lady came up to my room and said in a
253ğ“€´very hysterical way:
254ğ“€´
255ğ“€´â€œMust you go? Oh! young Herr, must you go?â€ She was in such an excited
256ğ“€´state that she seemed to have lost her grip of what German she knew, and
257ğ“€´mixed it all up with some other language which I did not know at all. I
258ğ“€´was just able to follow her by asking many questions. When I told her
259ğ“€´that I must go at once, and that I was engaged on important business,
260ğ“€´she asked again:
261ğ“€´
262ğ“€´â€œDo you know what day it is?â€ I answered that it was the fourth of May.
263ğ“€´She shook her head as she said again:
264ğ“€´
265ğ“€´â€œOh, yes! I know that! I know that, but do you know what day it is?â€ On
266ğ“€´my saying that I did not understand, she went on:
267ğ“€´
268ğ“€´â€œIt is the eve of St. Georgeâ€™s Day. Do you not know that to-night, when
269ğ“€´the clock strikes midnight, all the evil things in the world will have
270ğ“€´full sway? Do you know where you are going, and what you are going to?â€
271ğ“€´She was in such evident distress that I tried to comfort her, but
272ğ“€´without effect. Finally she went down on her knees and implored me not
273ğ“€´to go; at least to wait a day or two before starting. It was all very
274ğ“€´ridiculous but I did not feel comfortable. However, there was business
275ğ“€´to be done, and I could allow nothing to interfere with it. I therefore
276ğ“€´tried to raise her up, and said, as gravely as I could, that I thanked
277ğ“€´her, but my duty was imperative, and that I must go. She then rose and
278ğ“€´dried her eyes, and taking a crucifix from her neck offered it to me. I
279ğ“€´did not know what to do, for, as an English Churchman, I have been
280ğ“€´taught to regard such things as in some measure idolatrous, and yet it
281ğ“€´seemed so ungracious to refuse an old lady meaning so well and in such a
282ğ“€´state of mind. She saw, I suppose, the doubt in my face, for she put the
283ğ“€´rosary round my neck, and said, â€œFor your motherâ€™s sake,â€ and went out
284ğ“€´of the room. I am writing up this part of the diary whilst I am waiting
285ğ“€´for the coach, which is, of course, late; and the crucifix is still
286ğ“€´round my neck. Whether it is the old ladyâ€™s fear, or the many ghostly
287ğ“€´traditions of this place, or the crucifix itself, I do not know, but I
288ğ“€´am not feeling nearly as easy in my mind as usual. If this book should
289ğ“€´ever reach Mina before I do, let it bring my good-bye. Here comes the
290ğ“€´coach!
291ğ“€´
292ğ“€´       *       *       *       *       *
293ğ“€´
294ğ“€´_5 May. The Castle._--The grey of the morning has passed, and the sun is
295ğ“€´high over the distant horizon, which seems jagged, whether with trees or
296ğ“€´hills I know not, for it is so far off that big things and little are
297ğ“€´mixed. I am not sleepy, and, as I am not to be called till I awake,
298ğ“€´naturally I write till sleep comes. There are many odd things to put
299ğ“€´down, and, lest who reads them may fancy that I dined too well before I
300ğ“€´left Bistritz, let me put down my dinner exactly. I dined on what they
301ğ“€´called â€œrobber steakâ€--bits of bacon, onion, and beef, seasoned with red
302ğ“€´pepper, and strung on sticks and roasted over the fire, in the simple
303ğ“€´style of the London catâ€™s meat! The wine was Golden Mediasch, which
304ğ“€´produces a queer sting on the tongue, which is, however, not
305ğ“€´disagreeable. I had only a couple of glasses of this, and nothing else.
306ğ“€´
307ğ“€´When I got on the coach the driver had not taken his seat, and I saw him
308ğ“€´talking with the landlady. They were evidently talking of me, for every
309ğ“€´now and then they looked at me, and some of the people who were sitting
310ğ“€´on the bench outside the door--which they call by a name meaning
311ğ“€´â€œword-bearerâ€--came and listened, and then looked at me, most of them
312ğ“€´pityingly. I could hear a lot of words often repeated, queer words, for
313ğ“€´there were many nationalities in the crowd; so I quietly got my polyglot
314ğ“€´dictionary from my bag and looked them out. I must say they were not
315ğ“€´cheering to me, for amongst them were â€œOrdogâ€--Satan, â€œpokolâ€--hell,
316ğ“€´â€œstregoicaâ€--witch, â€œvrolokâ€ and â€œvlkoslakâ€--both of which mean the same
317ğ“€´thing, one being Slovak and the other Servian for something that is
318ğ“€´either were-wolf or vampire. (_Mem._, I must ask the Count about these
319ğ“€´superstitions)
320ğ“€´
321ğ“€´When we started, the crowd round the inn door, which had by this time
322ğ“€´swelled to a considerable size, all made the sign of the cross and
323ğ“€´pointed two fingers towards me. With some difficulty I got a
324ğ“€´fellow-passenger to tell me what they meant; he would not answer at
325ğ“€´first, but on learning that I was English, he explained that it was a
326ğ“€´charm or guard against the evil eye. This was not very pleasant for me,
327ğ“€´just starting for an unknown place to meet an unknown man; but every one
328ğ“€´seemed so kind-hearted, and so sorrowful, and so sympathetic that I
329ğ“€´could not but be touched. I shall never forget the last glimpse which I
330ğ“€´had of the inn-yard and its crowd of picturesque figures, all crossing
331ğ“€´themselves, as they stood round the wide archway, with its background of
332ğ“€´rich foliage of oleander and orange trees in green tubs clustered in the
333ğ“€´centre of the yard. Then our driver, whose wide linen drawers covered
334ğ“€´the whole front of the box-seat--â€œgotzaâ€ they call them--cracked his big
335ğ“€´whip over his four small horses, which ran abreast, and we set off on
336ğ“€´our journey.
337ğ“€´
338ğ“€´I soon lost sight and recollection of ghostly fears in the beauty of the
339ğ“€´scene as we drove along, although had I known the language, or rather
340ğ“€´languages, which my fellow-passengers were speaking, I might not have
341ğ“€´been able to throw them off so easily. Before us lay a green sloping
342ğ“€´land full of forests and woods, with here and there steep hills, crowned
343ğ“€´with clumps of trees or with farmhouses, the blank gable end to the
344ğ“€´road. There was everywhere a bewildering mass of fruit blossom--apple,
345ğ“€´plum, pear, cherry; and as we drove by I could see the green grass under
346ğ“€´the trees spangled with the fallen petals. In and out amongst these
347ğ“€´green hills of what they call here the â€œMittel Landâ€ ran the road,
348ğ“€´losing itself as it swept round the grassy curve, or was shut out by the
349ğ“€´straggling ends of pine woods, which here and there ran down the
350ğ“€´hillsides like tongues of flame. The road was rugged, but still we
351ğ“€´seemed to fly over it with a feverish haste. I could not understand then
352ğ“€´what the haste meant, but the driver was evidently bent on losing no
353ğ“€´time in reaching Borgo Prund. I was told that this road is in summertime
354ğ“€´excellent, but that it had not yet been put in order after the winter
355ğ“€´snows. In this respect it is different from the general run of roads in
356ğ“€´the Carpathians, for it is an old tradition that they are not to be kept
357ğ“€´in too good order. Of old the Hospadars would not repair them, lest the
358ğ“€´Turk should think that they were preparing to bring in foreign troops,
359ğ“€´and so hasten the war which was always really at loading point.
360ğ“€´
361ğ“€´Beyond the green swelling hills of the Mittel Land rose mighty slopes
362ğ“€´of forest up to the lofty steeps of the Carpathians themselves. Right
363ğ“€´and left of us they towered, with the afternoon sun falling full upon
364ğ“€´them and bringing out all the glorious colours of this beautiful range,
365ğ“€´deep blue and purple in the shadows of the peaks, green and brown where
366ğ“€´grass and rock mingled, and an endless perspective of jagged rock and
367ğ“€´pointed crags, till these were themselves lost in the distance, where
368ğ“€´the snowy peaks rose grandly. Here and there seemed mighty rifts in the
369ğ“€´mountains, through which, as the sun began to sink, we saw now and again
370ğ“€´the white gleam of falling water. One of my companions touched my arm as
371ğ“€´we swept round the base of a hill and opened up the lofty, snow-covered
372ğ“€´peak of a mountain, which seemed, as we wound on our serpentine way, to
373ğ“€´be right before us:--
374ğ“€´
375ğ“€´â€œLook! Isten szek!â€--â€œGodâ€™s seat!â€--and he crossed himself reverently.
376ğ“€´
377ğ“€´As we wound on our endless way, and the sun sank lower and lower behind
378ğ“€´us, the shadows of the evening began to creep round us. This was
379ğ“€´emphasised by the fact that the snowy mountain-top still held the
380ğ“€´sunset, and seemed to glow out with a delicate cool pink. Here and there
381ğ“€´we passed Cszeks and Slovaks, all in picturesque attire, but I noticed
382ğ“€´that goitre was painfully prevalent. By the roadside were many crosses,
383ğ“€´and as we swept by, my companions all crossed themselves. Here and there
384ğ“€´was a peasant man or woman kneeling before a shrine, who did not even
385ğ“€´turn round as we approached, but seemed in the self-surrender of
386ğ“€´devotion to have neither eyes nor ears for the outer world. There were
387ğ“€´many things new to me: for instance, hay-ricks in the trees, and here
388ğ“€´and there very beautiful masses of weeping birch, their white stems
389ğ“€´shining like silver through the delicate green of the leaves. Now and
390ğ“€´again we passed a leiter-wagon--the ordinary peasantâ€™s cart--with its
391ğ“€´long, snake-like vertebra, calculated to suit the inequalities of the
392ğ“€´road. On this were sure to be seated quite a group of home-coming
393ğ“€´peasants, the Cszeks with their white, and the Slovaks with their
394ğ“€´coloured, sheepskins, the latter carrying lance-fashion their long
395ğ“€´staves, with axe at end. As the evening fell it began to get very cold,
396ğ“€´and the growing twilight seemed to merge into one dark mistiness the
397ğ“€´gloom of the trees, oak, beech, and pine, though in the valleys which
398ğ“€´ran deep between the spurs of the hills, as we ascended through the
399ğ“€´Pass, the dark firs stood out here and there against the background of
400ğ“€´late-lying snow. Sometimes, as the road was cut through the pine woods
401ğ“€´that seemed in the darkness to be closing down upon us, great masses of
402ğ“€´greyness, which here and there bestrewed the trees, produced a
403ğ“€´peculiarly weird and solemn effect, which carried on the thoughts and
404ğ“€´grim fancies engendered earlier in the evening, when the falling sunset
405ğ“€´threw into strange relief the ghost-like clouds which amongst the
406ğ“€´Carpathians seem to wind ceaselessly through the valleys. Sometimes the
407ğ“€´hills were so steep that, despite our driverâ€™s haste, the horses could
408ğ“€´only go slowly. I wished to get down and walk up them, as we do at home,
409ğ“€´but the driver would not hear of it. â€œNo, no,â€ he said; â€œyou must not
410ğ“€´walk here; the dogs are too fierceâ€; and then he added, with what he
411ğ“€´evidently meant for grim pleasantry--for he looked round to catch the
412ğ“€´approving smile of the rest--â€œand you may have enough of such matters
413ğ“€´before you go to sleep.â€ The only stop he would make was a momentâ€™s
414ğ“€´pause to light his lamps.
415ğ“€´
416ğ“€´When it grew dark there seemed to be some excitement amongst the

2461ğ“€´_25 May._--Ebb tide in appetite to-day. Cannot eat, cannot rest, so
2462ğ“€´diary instead. Since my rebuff of yesterday I have a sort of empty
2463ğ“€´feeling; nothing in the world seems of sufficient importance to be worth

2466ğ“€´afforded me a study of much interest. He is so quaint that I am
2467ğ“€´determined to understand him as well as I can. To-day I seemed to get
2468ğ“€´nearer than ever before to the heart of his mystery.
2469ğ“€´
2470ğ“€´I questioned him more fully than I had ever done, with a view to making

2472ğ“€´it there was, I now see, something of cruelty. I seemed to wish to keep
2473ğ“€´him to the point of his madness--a thing which I avoid with the patients

2481ğ“€´R. M. Renfield, Ã¦tat 59.--Sanguine temperament; great physical strength;

3065ğ“€´_Whitby_.
3066ğ“€´
3067ğ“€´One of the greatest and suddenest storms on record has just been
3068ğ“€´experienced here, with results both strange and unique. The weather had
3069ğ“€´been somewhat sultry, but not to any degree uncommon in the month of
3070ğ“€´August. Saturday evening was as fine as was ever known, and the great
3071ğ“€´body of holiday-makers laid out yesterday for visits to Mulgrave Woods,
3072ğ“€´Robin Hoodâ€™s Bay, Rig Mill, Runswick, Staithes, and the various trips in
3073ğ“€´the neighbourhood of Whitby. The steamers _Emma_ and _Scarborough_ made
3074ğ“€´trips up and down the coast, and there was an unusual amount of
3075ğ“€´â€œtrippingâ€ both to and from Whitby. The day was unusually fine till the
3076ğ“€´afternoon, when some of the gossips who frequent the East Cliff
3077ğ“€´churchyard, and from that commanding eminence watch the wide sweep of
3078ğ“€´sea visible to the north and east, called attention to a sudden show of
3079ğ“€´â€œmaresâ€™-tailsâ€ high in the sky to the north-west. The wind was then
3080ğ“€´blowing from the south-west in the mild degree which in barometrical
3081ğ“€´language is ranked â€œNo. 2: light breeze.â€ The coastguard on duty at once
3082ğ“€´made report, and one old fisherman, who for more than half a century has
3083ğ“€´kept watch on weather signs from the East Cliff, foretold in an emphatic
3084ğ“€´manner the coming of a sudden storm. The approach of sunset was so very
3085ğ“€´beautiful, so grand in its masses of splendidly-coloured clouds, that
3086ğ“€´there was quite an assemblage on the walk along the cliff in the old
3087ğ“€´churchyard to enjoy the beauty. Before the sun dipped below the black
3088ğ“€´mass of Kettleness, standing boldly athwart the western sky, its
3089ğ“€´downward way was marked by myriad clouds of every sunset-colour--flame,
3090ğ“€´purple, pink, green, violet, and all the tints of gold; with here and
3091ğ“€´there masses not large, but of seemingly absolute blackness, in all
3092ğ“€´sorts of shapes, as well outlined as colossal silhouettes. The
3093ğ“€´experience was not lost on the painters, and doubtless some of the

3095ğ“€´I. walls in May next. More than one captain made up his mind then and
3096ğ“€´there that his â€œcobbleâ€ or his â€œmule,â€ as they term the different
3097ğ“€´classes of boats, would remain in the harbour till the storm had passed.
3098ğ“€´The wind fell away entirely during the evening, and at midnight there

3100ğ“€´the approach of thunder, affects persons of a sensitive nature. There

3102ğ“€´which usually â€œhugâ€ the shore so closely, kept well to seaward, and but

3105ğ“€´foolhardiness or ignorance of her officers was a prolific theme for

3110ğ“€´
3111ğ“€´    â€œAs idle as a painted ship upon a painted ocean.â€

3119ğ“€´carry a strange, faint, hollow booming.
3120ğ“€´

3318ğ“€´On 6 July we finished taking in cargo, silver sand and boxes of earth.

3329ğ“€´On 12 July through Dardanelles. More Customs officers and flagboat of

3340ğ“€´On 14 July was somewhat anxious about crew. Men all steady fellows, who
3341ğ“€´sailed with me before. Mate could not make out what was wrong; they only
3342ğ“€´told him there was _something_, and crossed themselves. Mate lost temper
3343ğ“€´with one of them that day and struck him. Expected fierce quarrel, but
3344ğ“€´all was quiet.

3348ğ“€´On 16 July mate reported in the morning that one of crew, Petrofsky, was
3349ğ“€´missing. Could not account for it. Took larboard watch eight bells last
3350ğ“€´night; was relieved by Abramoff, but did not go to bunk. Men more
3351ğ“€´downcast than ever. All said they expected something of the kind, but
3352ğ“€´would not say more than there was _something_ aboard. Mate getting very
3353ğ“€´impatient with them; feared some trouble ahead.

3356ğ“€´
3357ğ“€´On 17 July, yesterday, one of the men, Olgaren, came to my cabin, and in
3358ğ“€´an awestruck way confided to me that he thought there was a strange man
3359ğ“€´aboard the ship. He said that in his watch he had been sheltering
3360ğ“€´behind the deck-house, as there was a rain-storm, when he saw a tall,
3361ğ“€´thin man, who was not like any of the crew, come up the companion-way,
3362ğ“€´and go along the deck forward, and disappear. He followed cautiously,
3363ğ“€´but when he got to bows found no one, and the hatchways were all closed.
3364ğ“€´He was in a panic of superstitious fear, and I am afraid the panic may
3365ğ“€´spread. To allay it, I shall to-day search entire ship carefully from
3366ğ“€´stem to stern.

3369ğ“€´
3370ğ“€´Later in the day I got together the whole crew, and told them, as they

3373ğ“€´foolish ideas would demoralise the men; said he would engage to keep
3374ğ“€´them out of trouble with a handspike. I let him take the helm, while the
3375ğ“€´rest began thorough search, all keeping abreast, with lanterns: we left
3376ğ“€´no corner unsearched. As there were only the big wooden boxes, there
3377ğ“€´were no odd corners where a man could hide. Men much relieved when
3378ğ“€´search over, and went back to work cheerfully. First mate scowled, but

15281ğ“€´spoken. Instinctively they reined in, and at the instant Lord Godalming
15282ğ“€´and Jonathan dashed up at one side and Dr. Seward and Mr. Morris on the
15283ğ“€´other. The leader of the gypsies, a splendid-looking fellow who sat his
15284ğ“€´horse like a centaur, waved them back, and in a fierce voice gave to his
15285ğ“€´companions some word to proceed. They lashed the horses which sprang
15286ğ“€´forward; but the four men raised their Winchester rifles, and in an
15287ğ“€´unmistakable way commanded them to stop. At the same moment Dr. Van
15288ğ“€´Helsing and I rose behind the rock and pointed our weapons at them.
15289ğ“€´Seeing that they were surrounded the men tightened their reins and drew
15290ğ“€´up. The leader turned to them and gave a word at which every man of the
15291ğ“€´gypsy party drew what weapon he carried, knife or pistol, and held
15292ğ“€´himself in readiness to attack. Issue was joined in an instant.
15293ğ“€´
15294ğ“€´The leader, with a quick movement of his rein, threw his horse out in
15295ğ“€´front, and pointing first to the sun--now close down on the hill
15296ğ“€´tops--and then to the castle, said something which I did not understand.
15297ğ“€´For answer, all four men of our party threw themselves from their horses
15298ğ“€´and dashed towards the cart. I should have felt terrible fear at seeing
15299ğ“€´Jonathan in such danger, but that the ardour of battle must have been
15300ğ“€´upon me as well as the rest of them; I felt no fear, but only a wild,
15301ğ“€´surging desire to do something. Seeing the quick movement of our
15302ğ“€´parties, the leader of the gypsies gave a command; his men instantly
15303ğ“€´formed round the cart in a sort of undisciplined endeavour, each one
15304ğ“€´shouldering and pushing the other in his eagerness to carry out the
15305ğ“€´order.
15306ğ“€´
15307ğ“€´In the midst of this I could see that Jonathan on one side of the ring
15308ğ“€´of men, and Quincey on the other, were forcing a way to the cart; it was
15309ğ“€´evident that they were bent on finishing their task before the sun
15310ğ“€´should set. Nothing seemed to stop or even to hinder them. Neither the
15311ğ“€´levelled weapons nor the flashing knives of the gypsies in front, nor
15312ğ“€´the howling of the wolves behind, appeared to even attract their
15313ğ“€´attention. Jonathanâ€™s impetuosity, and the manifest singleness of his
15314ğ“€´purpose, seemed to overawe those in front of him; instinctively they
15315ğ“€´cowered, aside and let him pass. In an instant he had jumped upon the
15316ğ“€´cart, and, with a strength which seemed incredible, raised the great
15317ğ“€´box, and flung it over the wheel to the ground. In the meantime, Mr.
15318ğ“€´Morris had had to use force to pass through his side of the ring of
15319ğ“€´Szgany. All the time I had been breathlessly watching Jonathan I had,
15320ğ“€´with the tail of my eye, seen him pressing desperately forward, and had
15321ğ“€´seen the knives of the gypsies flash as he won a way through them, and
15322ğ“€´they cut at him. He had parried with his great bowie knife, and at first
15323ğ“€´I thought that he too had come through in safety; but as he sprang
15324ğ“€´beside Jonathan, who had by now jumped from the cart, I could see that
15325ğ“€´with his left hand he was clutching at his side, and that the blood was
15326ğ“€´spurting through his fingers. He did not delay notwithstanding this, for
15327ğ“€´as Jonathan, with desperate energy, attacked one end of the chest,
15328ğ“€´attempting to prize off the lid with his great Kukri knife, he attacked
15329ğ“€´the other frantically with his bowie. Under the efforts of both men the
15330ğ“€´lid began to yield; the nails drew with a quick screeching sound, and
15331ğ“€´the top of the box was thrown back.
15332ğ“€´
15333ğ“€´By this time the gypsies, seeing themselves covered by the Winchesters,
15334ğ“€´and at the mercy of Lord Godalming and Dr. Seward, had given in and made
15335ğ“€´no resistance. The sun was almost down on the mountain tops, and the
15336ğ“€´shadows of the whole group fell long upon the snow. I saw the Count
15337ğ“€´lying within the box upon the earth, some of which the rude falling from
15338ğ“€´the cart had scattered over him. He was deathly pale, just like a waxen
15339ğ“€´image, and the red eyes glared with the horrible vindictive look which I
15340ğ“€´knew too well.
15341ğ“€´
15342ğ“€´As I looked, the eyes saw the sinking sun, and the look of hate in them
15343ğ“€´turned to triumph.
15344ğ“€´
15345ğ“€´But, on the instant, came the sweep and flash of Jonathanâ€™s great knife.
15346ğ“€´I shrieked as I saw it shear through the throat; whilst at the same
15347ğ“€´moment Mr. Morrisâ€™s bowie knife plunged into the heart.
15348ğ“€´
15349ğ“€´It was like a miracle; but before our very eyes, and almost in the
15350ğ“€´drawing of a breath, the whole body crumbled into dust and passed from
15351ğ“€´our sight.
15352ğ“€´
15353ğ“€´I shall be glad as long as I live that even in that moment of final
15354ğ“€´dissolution, there was in the face a look of peace, such as I never
15355ğ“€´could have imagined might have rested there.
15356ğ“€´
15357ğ“€´The Castle of Dracula now stood out against the red sky, and every stone
15358ğ“€´of its broken battlements was articulated against the light of the
15359ğ“€´setting sun.
15360ğ“€´
15361ğ“€´The gypsies, taking us as in some way the cause of the extraordinary
15362ğ“€´disappearance of the dead man, turned, without a word, and rode away as
15363ğ“€´if for their lives. Those who were unmounted jumped upon the
15364ğ“€´leiter-wagon and shouted to the horsemen not to desert them. The wolves,
15365ğ“€´which had withdrawn to a safe distance, followed in their wake, leaving
15366ğ“€´us alone.
15367ğ“€´
15368ğ“€´Mr. Morris, who had sunk to the ground, leaned on his elbow, holding his
15369ğ“€´hand pressed to his side; the blood still gushed through his fingers. I
15370ğ“€´flew to him, for the Holy circle did not now keep me back; so did the
15371ğ“€´two doctors. Jonathan knelt behind him and the wounded man laid back his
15372ğ“€´head on his shoulder. With a sigh he took, with a feeble effort, my hand
15373ğ“€´in that of his own which was unstained. He must have seen the anguish of
15374ğ“€´my heart in my face, for he smiled at me and said:--
15375ğ“€´
15376ğ“€´â€œI am only too happy to have been of any service! Oh, God!â€ he cried
15377ğ“€´suddenly, struggling up to a sitting posture and pointing to me, â€œIt was
15378ğ“€´worth for this to die! Look! look!â€
15379ğ“€´
15380ğ“€´The sun was now right down upon the mountain top, and the red gleams
15381ğ“€´fell upon my face, so that it was bathed in rosy light. With one impulse
15382ğ“€´the men sank on their knees and a deep and earnest â€œAmenâ€ broke from all
15383ğ“€´as their eyes followed the pointing of his finger. The dying man
15384ğ“€´spoke:--
15385ğ“€´
15386ğ“€´â€œNow God be thanked that all has not been in vain! See! the snow is not
15387ğ“€´more stainless than her forehead! The curse has passed away!â€
15388ğ“€´
15389ğ“€´And, to our bitter grief, with a smile and in silence, he died, a
15390ğ“€´gallant gentleman.
15391ğ“€´

15395ğ“€´                                  NOTE
15396ğ“€´
15397ğ“€´
15398ğ“€´Seven years ago we all went through the flames; and the happiness of
15399ğ“€´some of us since then is, we think, well worth the pain we endured. It
15400ğ“€´is an added joy to Mina and to me that our boyâ€™s birthday is the same
15401ğ“€´day as that on which Quincey Morris died. His mother holds, I know, the
15402ğ“€´secret belief that some of our brave friendâ€™s spirit has passed into
15403ğ“€´him. His bundle of names links all our little band of men together; but
15404ğ“€´we call him Quincey.
15405ğ“€´
15406ğ“€´In the summer of this year we made a journey to Transylvania, and went
15407ğ“€´over the old ground which was, and is, to us so full of vivid and
15408ğ“€´terrible memories. It was almost impossible to believe that the things
15409ğ“€´which we had seen with our own eyes and heard with our own ears were
15410ğ“€´living truths. Every trace of all that had been was blotted out. The
15411ğ“€´castle stood as before, reared high above a waste of desolation.
15412ğ“€´
15413ğ“€´When we got home we were talking of the old time--which we could all
15414ğ“€´look back on without despair, for Godalming and Seward are both happily
15415ğ“€´married. I took the papers from the safe where they had been ever since
15416ğ“€´our return so long ago. We were struck with the fact, that in all the
15417ğ“€´mass of material of which the record is composed, there is hardly one
15418ğ“€´authentic document; nothing but a mass of typewriting, except the later
15419ğ“€´note-books of Mina and Seward and myself, and Van Helsingâ€™s memorandum.
15420ğ“€´We could hardly ask any one, even did we wish to, to accept these as
15421ğ“€´proofs of so wild a story. Van Helsing summed it all up as he said, with
15422ğ“€´our boy on his knee:--
15423ğ“€´
15424ğ“€´â€œWe want no proofs; we ask none to believe us! This boy will some day
15425ğ“€´know what a brave and gallant woman his mother is. Already he knows her
15426ğ“€´sweetness and loving care; later on he will understand how some men so
15427ğ“€´loved her, that they did dare much for her sake.â€
15428ğ“€´
